title: Forgot Bedtime Steps
wrong_way: What are you doing? I told you, PJs, then teeth! Why don't you listen?
phrase_1: [Gently touch shoulder]. Hey, I need your eyes right here. I see you're playing with the car. You forgot what's next, didn't you?
say_it_like_this_step1: Walk over to them. Get to eye level and use a gentle, physical touch to get their attention. Use a kind, knowing tone. Not angry.
avoid_step1: Don't yell from the doorway. Don't assume they are defying you. Don't list all the steps they forgot.
phrase_2: That's okay! It's a lot to remember. AND it's bedtime. Let's look at our chart. What's the *first* step?
say_it_like_this_step2: Point to a visual schedule (e.g., a chart with pictures). Speak slowly. Focus only on *one* step.
avoid_step2: Don't say 'but'. Don't overwhelm them with the *whole* list. Don't show frustration that they forgot.
phrase_3: 'PJs'! You got it. You are in charge of that one step. Go put your PJs on, and then come and show me. I'll tell you the next step.
say_it_like_this_step3: Give them *one single task*. Make 'coming back to you' the end of that task. This provides the external structure they need.
avoid_step3: Don't give the next step yet. Don't expect them to remember 'PJs *and* teeth'. Just 'PJs'.
neurological_tip: A distracted child's working memory is limited. They aren't defiant; they're overloaded. Giving one instruction at a time prevents cognitive overload and 'task-dropping'.
what_to_expect_1: You will have to guide them, step by step, through the entire routine.
what_to_expect_2: This is not babying them; it's providing essential executive function support.
what_to_expect_3: Visual charts are not a 'nice-to-have'; they are critical external memory aids.

title: Gets Up Repeatedly
wrong_way: If you get out of that bed one more time, I'm taking away the iPad tomorrow!
phrase_1: [Calmly walk them back. No emotion]. Hi again. I need your eyes. You're out of bed.
say_it_like_this_step1: Be a calm, boring 'robot'. No anger, no fun, no frustration. Gently take their hand.
avoid_step1: Don't show emotion. Don't get into a conversation. Don't make it a fun game.
phrase_2: It's easy to forget the rule when your brain thinks of something fun, AND the rule is 'stay in bed'. What's the rule?
say_it_like_this_step2: Keep it simple. 'The rule is...' State it clearly. Have them repeat it.
avoid_step2: Don't ask 'Why did you get up?'. This invites a long, distracting conversation.
phrase_3: Right, 'stay in bed'. You're in charge of your body. Let's get it back under the covers. I'll see you in the morning.
say_it_like_this_step3: Lead them back, make them get in. Quick, boring, loving pat. Leave. Repeat as many times as needed.
avoid_step3: Don't tuck them in again, read another story, or give extra hugs. This *must* be boring.
neurological_tip: This is an impulse-control and working memory issue, not defiance. They forget the 'staying in' part. A boring, robotic response makes it neurologically 'unrewarding' to get up.
what_to_expect_1: You may have to do this 10 times the first night. Consistency is the only thing that works.
what_to_expect_2: They aren't doing it to make you mad; their impulse control is 'offline' at night.

title: Distracted During Story
wrong_way: Sit still! If you can't be calm for a story, then no story!
phrase_1: I see your body is very 'wiggly' right now. It's hard to be still and listen at the same time.
say_it_like_this_step1: Pause the story. Use a gentle, observant tone. Put your hand on their arm.
avoid_step1: Don't threaten to take the story away (a beloved connection point). Don't sound angry.
phrase_2: Your body has 'wiggles', AND it's story time. Let's give those wiggles a job. Do you want to squeeze this 'fidget' or wear the 'heavy' (weighted) lap pad?
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the 'wiggles'. Offer a *sensory* choice that *helps* focus, rather than punishing the lack of it.
avoid_step2: Don't just say 'Stop wiggling'. Don't offer a 'toy' (that's another distraction).
phrase_3: You're in charge of your wiggles. Let's see if that heavy pad helps your body settle. Show me. Okay, back to the story.
say_it_like_this_step3: Empower them by giving them a *tool* to manage their distraction. You're making them an active participant in their own regulation.
avoid_step3: Don't expect perfect stillness. The goal is 'less' wiggling, not 'no' wiggling.
neurological_tip: Distracted children often need *more* sensory input (proprioception, tactile) to free up their *auditory* processing. A fidget or weighted pad provides this, 'grounding' their brain.
what_to_expect_1: A 'wiggle' is often the brain's attempt to self-regulate. Your job is to make that attempt 'productive'.
what_to_expect_2: This teaches them a lifelong skill of using sensory tools to focus.

title: Can't Settle Down (Hyperfocus)
wrong_way: It's 8:30! You were supposed to be in bed 30 minutes ago! Why are you still playing Legos?
phrase_1: [Gently touch shoulder]. Hey. I need to 'pause' your brain. [Wait for eye contact]. You are *deep* in the Lego 'zone'. You didn't hear me at all.
say_it_like_this_step1: Get in their physical space (kindly). Use a physical 'pause' button (the touch).
avoid_step1: Don't yell from the hall. Don't assume they ignored you (they 100% did not hear you).
phrase_2: That focus is an amazing superpower, AND the timer for bedtime went off. (Point to a *visual* timer). It's time to stop. Your *one* job: find a 'stopping point' in the next 60 seconds.
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the hyperfocus as a *strength* ('superpower'). State the *visual* boundary (timer). Give a *one-step* command ('find a stopping point').
avoid_step2: Don't just say 'Stop now'. That's neurologically jarring. Don't just turn off the light.
phrase_3: You're in charge of the 'pause' button. Show me where you'll stop. [Wait]. Great. Now, stand up. That's Step 1. Come with me for Step 2.
say_it_like_this_step3: Empower them to control *how* they stop. Then, physically guide them to the *next* single step (stand up, walk with me).
avoid_step3: Don't assume they know what 'get ready for bed' means. You must guide them.
neurological_tip: Hyperfocus is the flip side of distractibility. The brain gets 'stuck'. A verbal command can't get in. A physical touch and a visual timer are needed to break the 'trance'.
what_to_expect_1: They will likely be disoriented. Be gentle and guide them one step at a time.
what_to_expect_2: Using a 'blinking' light timer in addition to an audio one is highly effective.

title: Won't Turn Off (Forgot Warning)
wrong_way: I told you 5 minutes ago! That's it, time's up! Give me that!
phrase_1: [Walk over. Get between them and screen. Touch shoulder]. Hey, I need your eyes. You're in the 'zone' and didn't hear me.
say_it_like_this_step1: Physical presence is non-negotiable. Get down to their level. Be calm.
avoid_step1: Don't yell from across the room. Don't grab the device. Don't assume they're being defiant.
phrase_2: You're loving that game, AND the timer is done. (Point to a *visual* timer, like a TimeTimer). It's time for Step 1: Pause. You're in charge of the pause button.
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the focus. State the *visual* boundary. Give a *micro-step* ('pause').
avoid_step2: Don't say 'Turn it off'. That's too big. 'Pause' is the first, achievable step.
phrase_3: Great! Step 1 is done. You're in charge of Step 2: The 'off' button. Show me. [Wait]. Perfect. Now, what's our *next* activity? (Point to visual schedule).
say_it_like_this_step3: Empower them by breaking 'turn it off' into two separate steps. Then immediately point them to the *next* concrete thing on the schedule.
avoid_step3: Don't walk away after 'pause'. They will 'forget' Step 2. Stay there.
neurological_tip: They genuinely do not hear you. Their brain is filtering you out. You must use physical proximity and a visual cue (the timer) to break through.
what_to_expect_1: The two-step 'pause' then 'off' gives their brain a moment to transition, preventing a 'crash'.
what_to_expect_2: A visual timer they can see *while playing* is the most important tool.

title: Meltdown (Overstimulated)
wrong_way: Stop this! You're acting crazy. If you can't handle it, no more screens ever!
phrase_1: Whoa! Your body is full of 'static electricity' from the screen. It's 'buzzy' and out of control. Your brain is going too fast!
say_it_like_this_step1: Use a strong, clear voice (not angry). Name the *physical* feeling ('buzzy', 'static').
avoid_step1: Don't say 'Stop crying'. Don't threaten. Don't try to reason. Don't blame them.
phrase_2: That's a 'too-much' feeling, AND we need to get that energy out. Let's do a 'brain reset'. Your job is one thing: 10 wall push-ups. Ready?
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the *physical* overwhelm. Give a *single* command that is *physical*.
avoid_step2: Don't offer a 'calm' activity (like reading). The body *needs* to move to regulate.
phrase_3: Go! Push that 'buzzy' feeling into the wall. You're in charge of resetting your brain. [Count with them]. Great! Next step: a cold drink of water.
say_it_like_this_step3: Empower them with a *physical tool*. Proprioceptive input (wall push-ups, stomping) is neurologically calming and 'resets' a 'scrambled' nervous system.
avoid_step3: Don't talk *about* the meltdown. Just give the physical, step-by-step instructions.
neurological_tip: Screen transitions are neurologically difficult. A 'distracted' brain needs a physical, sensory 'off-ramp' to transition from high-stim to low-stim. This is a tool, not a punishment.
what_to_expect_1: They will likely do it and feel better, but be confused. That's okay.
what_to_expect_2: It's a physical 'reboot'. It works.

title: Keeps Asking for Screens
wrong_way: How many times do I have to tell you? No! Stop asking me!
phrase_1: Hey, I need your eyes. You're asking for the tablet again. You're having a hard time remembering the 'no'.
say_it_like_this_step1: Get eye contact. Be kind but firm. Acknowledge the *forgetting*.
avoid_step1: Don't get angry. Don't say 'Stop asking'. Don't just keep repeating 'no' verbally.
phrase_2: It's hard to hold the 'plan' in your head, AND the answer is still 'at 4 PM'. Let's make a 'brain helper'. Your job: let's draw the clock at 4 PM and tape it to the fridge.
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the *working memory* challenge. State the boundary. Offer a *visual tool* as the solution.
avoid_step2: Don't say 'Maybe later'. Be concrete.
phrase_3: You're in charge of this picture. If your brain forgets, you can go look at your 'boss picture' to remember. Now, what's the *real* next thing on our plan? (Point to visual schedule).
say_it_like_this_step3: Empower them by making *them* the creator of their own 'external memory'. This visual cue now exists in the world, freeing up their working memory.
avoid_step3: Don't just make the drawing *for* them. The *act* of making it helps their brain.
neurological_tip: A verbal 'no' is invisible and gets 'lost' in a distracted brain. A *visual* 'no' (or 'yes, at 4') is permanent and provides the external structure they need.
what_to_expect_1: When they ask again, don't say 'no'. Say 'Go check the 'boss picture'!'
what_to_expect_2: This teaches them to use visual aids, a critical life skill for them.

title: Distracted By Screen (Won't Come to Dinner)
wrong_way: (Yelling from kitchen) Dinner! I'm not calling you again! Get in here right now!
phrase_1: [Walk over. Stand between them and screen. Wait. Gentle touch]. Hey. I'm right here. I need your eyes.

category: This is a 100% physical-presence-and-touch script. Do not speak until you have their attention.
profile: Don't yell from another room. It will never work. Don't be surprised they didn't 'listen'.
difficulty_level: You 100% did not hear me call for dinner, did you? That's okay. You were in the 'zone'. AND dinner is on the table. We need to do the 2 'off' steps. Step 1: Pause.
age_range: Be empathetic, not angry. 'You didn't hear me' (fact) vs. 'You ignored me' (accusation). Break the 'off' task into two steps.
duration_minutes: Don't give the multi-step command: 'Turn it off, wash your hands, and come to the table.' This is a 100% guaranteed failure.
wrong_way: Great. Step 2: Power button. [Wait]. Awesome. Now, *one* next step: walk to the kitchen sink. I'll walk with you.
phrase_1: Give *one* instruction at a time. Walk *with* them to the next 'station' (sink). This is 'scaffolding'.
say_it_like_this_step1: Don't expect them to complete the sequence alone. They will get sidetracked.
avoid_step1: A distracted child's brain *cannot* process a verbal command from another room while engaged in a high-stimulus activity. Proximity and single-step instructions are the only way.
phrase_2: At the sink, you'll give the *next* one-step command: 'Your job: wash hands.'
say_it_like_this_step2: This feels slow, but it's 100x faster than the 10-minute yelling match.
avoid_step2: Mealtime-Too Distracted to Eat|Transitions-Forgets Instructions

title: Too Distracted to Eat
wrong_way: Sit still. Stop looking at the dog. Eat your food. Stop wiggling.
phrase_1: Hey, I need your eyes on me. [Wait]. Your brain is noticing *everything* in the room *except* your food! Your eyes are all over.
say_it_like_this_step1: Get their attention. Use a gentle, playful 'I see you' tone.
avoid_step1: Don't just give a list of 'stop' commands. Don't get frustrated.
phrase_2: It's hard to focus when so much is happening, AND it's time to eat. Let's get your 'Focuser' on. Your job: take *one* 'super-bite' right now. Show me.
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the distraction. Give them *one* single, achievable task ('one bite').
avoid_step2: Don't say 'Eat your dinner'. That's too big a task.
phrase_3: You did it! Great. Now, your next job: let's see if you can take *two* more bites before this 1-minute sand timer runs out. You're in charge of racing the timer.
say_it_like_this_step3: Empower them by 'gamifying' the focus. A visual sand timer provides a concrete, external focus point. You're breaking the meal into 1-minute 'sprints'.
avoid_step3: Don't expect 20 minutes of focus. Expect 1-2 minutes, then reset.
neurological_tip: They are not being defiant; their brain is genuinely pulled by other stimuli. Breaking it down into 'one bite' and using a visual timer provides the external structure to support focus.
what_to_expect_1: This is a 'task-initiation' problem. The first bite is the hardest.
what_to_expect_2: You may need to use the timer 3-4 times during the meal.
what_to_expect_3: Mealtime-Gets Up from Table|Screens-Distracted By Screen

title: Forgets to Eat (Playing with Food)
wrong_way: Stop playing! Food is for eating! You're making a mess!
phrase_1: [Gentle touch on hand]. Hey buddy. Your hands are busy building a 'potato mountain', but your mouth isn't! You forgot what you were doing.
say_it_like_this_step1: Use a kind, observational tone. Gently stop the hand that is 'playing'.
avoid_step1: Don't get angry. Don't shame the 'playing' (it's often just their brain 'drifting').
phrase_2: Potato mountains are cool, AND dinner is for eating. Let's get back on track. What's the *first* step to eating? (e.g., 'fork').
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the 'drift'. State the boundary. Then ask a 'Step 1' question.
avoid_step2: Don't just say 'Eat!'
phrase_3: Right! Pick up your fork. That's Step 1. Great. You're in charge of Step 2: find a piece of chicken. [Narrate]. Good! Step 3: in your mouth. You did it!
say_it_like_this_step3: Empower them by narrating the micro-steps. You are *being* their external executive function, guiding them step-by-step.
avoid_step3: Don't expect them to 'get it' and finish. You may have to re-narrate this 2-3 times.
neurological_tip: This is often a failure of 'task initiation' or 'task-monitoring'. They get 'stuck' or 'drift' and genuinely forget the *goal* (eating). Narrating the steps is a verbal scaffold.
what_to_expect_1: They are not trying to be 'bad'. Their brain just 'changed channels'.
what_to_expect_2: This keeps the meal calm and moves it forward.
what_to_expect_3: Mealtime-Too Distracted to Eat|Hygiene-Distracted in Bath

title: Gets Up from Table Repeatedly
wrong_way: Get back in that chair! This is the third time! Where are you going now?
phrase_1: Whoa! You're up again! Your body is fast. [Gentle hand on shoulder, guide back]. I need your body to come back to the chair.
say_it_like_this_step1: Use a calm, neutral, 'robot' voice. No anger. Just a physical, gentle guide back.
avoid_step1: Don't get angry. Don't ask 'Why?' (you'll get a 10-minute story about a speck on the floor).
phrase_2: Your legs are 'wiggles'. It's hard to sit for a long time. AND the rule is 'bottoms in chairs at dinner'. Let's give your 'wiggles' a job. Can your feet 'tap dance' under the chair *while* your top half eats?
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the *need* to move. State the rule. Offer a *redirection* for the movement that is *compatible* with the rule.
avoid_step2: Don't say 'Stop wiggling'. This is like asking them to stop breathing.
phrase_3: You're in charge of the 'under-the-table-dance'. Let's see you do it. Great! Now, while your feet are busy, let's get that fork busy. One bite.
say_it_like_this_step3: Empower them by giving them control over the 'acceptable' wiggling. This 'grounds' their brain, which can *increase* focus on eating.
avoid_step3: Don't make the 'dance' too wild. 'Quiet tap dance' or 'pushing against my feet'.
neurological_tip: They *need* to move. Banning movement is futile and escalates the problem. *Redirecting* the movement to an acceptable channel (feet) allows their brain to get the sensory input it craves, which frees up focus.
what_to_expect_1: A 'wiggle cushion' (sensory cushion) or a 'stretchy band' around the chair legs can also work.
what_to_expect_2: This is a sensory need, not a behavioral problem.

title: Forgets to Come to Table (Lost in Play)
wrong_way: (Yelling from kitchen) Dinner! I'm not calling again! You'll eat cold food!
phrase_1: [Walk over. Eye level. Touch shoulder]. Hey. I need your brain for a second. [Wait for eye contact]. I just called for dinner. Did you hear me?

category: Walk. To. Them. This is 90% of the script. Get their full attention.
profile: Don't yell from another room. It is 100% ineffective. Don't take it personally.
difficulty_level: Nope! That's okay. You were in the 'zone'. AND it's time to eat. The *first* step is 'hands'. Let's go to the sink. I'll walk with you.
age_range: Acknowledge they *didn't* hear (not 'didn't listen'). State the boundary. Give *one* instruction ('hands') and then *scaffold* it ('I'll walk with you').
duration_minutes: Don't give the multi-step command: 'Turn it off, wash your hands, and come to the table.' This is a 100% guaranteed failure.
wrong_way: Great job washing. You're in charge of 'Step 2': finding your chair. Go sit down, and I'll bring your plate.
phrase_1: Give the *next* single step *after* the first is complete. You are their 'external brain' guiding them through the transition.
say_it_like_this_step1: Don't expect them to complete the sequence alone. They will get sidetracked (e.g., by the dog on the way to the table).
avoid_step1: A distracted child's brain *cannot* process a verbal command from another room while engaged in a high-stimulus activity. Proximity, eye contact, and single-step instructions are the only way.
phrase_2: This process, while feeling 'slow', is 10x faster than the 10-minute yelling match.
say_it_like_this_step2: This builds connection, not resentment.
avoid_step2: Transitions-Forgets Instructions|Morning_Routines-Forgetting Items

title: Resisting Activity Change (Lost in Play)
wrong_way: I warned you! We are leaving! Put that toy down NOW!
phrase_1: [Kneel down. Touch shoulder]. Hey, I need your eyes. You're deep in your play. It's hard to stop.
say_it_like_this_step1: Physical presence and touch are essential. Get their attention before you talk.
avoid_step1: Don't just yell 'Time to go!' from the door. Don't grab the toy.
phrase_2: You're having fun, AND the 5-minute timer is done. (Point to timer). It's time to go. Your *first* job is to put *one* toy in the bin. Show me.
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate. State the *visual* boundary (timer). Give *one micro-step*. 'Clean up' is too big. 'One toy in the bin' is achievable.
avoid_step2: Don't say 'It's time to clean up'. That's a huge, abstract task.
phrase_3: Great! Now *one* more. [Make it a game]. Okay, 2 toys are done. You're in charge of 'Step 2': standing up. Can you do it? [Wait]. Good! Step 3: walk to the door with me.
say_it_like_this_step3: Empower by breaking the 'leaving' process into 5-6 tiny, narrated steps. 'Stand up'. 'Walk to door'. You are 'being' their executive function.
avoid_step3: Don't rush them. Give 3-5 seconds for their brain to 'boot' each new command.
neurological_tip: Transitions are neurologically difficult for them. Their brain struggles to 'shift gears'. You have to be the 'clutch'. Narrating micro-steps is the only way to get through it without a meltdown.
what_to_expect_1: This isn't defiance, it's a 'cognitive flexibility' deficit.
what_to_expect_2: This 'hand-holding' (verbal and physical) is what builds their *future* ability to do it alone.

title: Forgets Instructions Mid-Task
wrong_way: What are you doing? I said get your shoes AND backpack! Why are you playing with the cat?
phrase_1: Hey, I need your eyes. [Gentle touch]. You got your shoes on! Awesome. And then you got sidetracked. It's hard to hold the *whole* list in your head.
say_it_like_this_step1: Be kind. Be an 'executive function' coach. You're a helper, not a critic.
avoid_step1: Don't show frustration. Don't say 'Why don't you ever listen?'. Don't list what they *didn't* do.
phrase_2: That's okay! You did Step 1. AND we still need 'Backpack'. That's the *only* thing to think about right now. Your 'Backpack Mission'. Go!
say_it_like_this_step2: Acknowledge the *success* (shoes). State the *one* next step. Turn it into a 'mission' (gamify).
avoid_step2: Don't say 'backpack AND lunchbox AND water bottle'. Just *one* thing.
phrase_3: Come back and show me the backpack. Then I'll give you the *next* (and final) step. You're in charge of the 'Backpack Mission'.
say_it_like_this_step3: Empower them by giving them *one* clear 'mission' at a time. The 'check-in' (come back and show me) is the critical loop.
avoid_step3: Don't give multi-step instructions *ever* and expect them to be remembered.
neurological_tip: Working memory fails *constantly*. This is not a moral failing; it's a brain-development fact. Breaking tasks into single 'missions' with a 'check-in' is the only way.
what_to_expect_1: Praise the completion of each micro-step. 'You did shoes! Yes!'
what_to_expect_2: Visual checklists by the door are the ultimate tool for this.

title: Impulsively Runs Off (e.g., in store)
wrong_way: Get back here! Don't you EVER run away from me! That is so dangerous!
phrase_1: [Secure them first. Kneel down. Hold both arms *gently*]. Hey. [Take a deep breath yourself]. I need your eyes. You saw something (shiny/fun) and your body moved *fast*. You forgot the rule.
say_it_like_this_step1: Get to their level. Your first job is *connection* and *calm*, even though your own heart is pounding. Your fear will escalate theirs.
avoid_step1: Don't scream. Don't shame them. Don't threaten. Your own amygdala is firing; you *must* calm it first.
phrase_2: You forgot. AND the rule is 'stay with me'. That was scary for me. Your job is *one* thing: hold my hand, or hold the 'shopping cart'. You choose.
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the *impulse* ('forgot'), don't blame. State the *rule*. State *your* feeling ('scary for me'). Give *one* clear 'job' with a choice.
avoid_step2: Don't say 'You scared me!' (blame). Say 'That was scary for me' (I-statement).
phrase_3: You are in charge of 'holding on'. Which will it be? Hand or cart?
say_it_like_this_step3: Empower them by giving them the 'job' of 'holding on'. This gives their brain *one thing* to focus on.
avoid_step3: Don't offer 'walking next to me'. This is too abstract. It must be a *physical connection*.
neurological_tip: This is a pure 'inhibitory control' failure. Their brain *saw* and *did* before the 'thinking' part could catch up. The 'job' (holding on) is an external, physical 'brake'.
what_to_expect_1: This requires 100% vigilance from you.
what_to_expect_2: This is not 'badness'. It is a terrifying lack of impulse control.

title: Can't Wait (Impulsive)
wrong_way: Stop asking! I'm busy! Wait your turn! You have to be patient!
phrase_1: I know, you have something important to say! It's hard to hold it in your brain. Your brain wants to 'say it now!'
say_it_like_this_step1: Use a kind 'I see you' tone. Acknowledge the *urgency* they feel.
avoid_step1: Don't just say 'Wait!' or 'Be patient!'. This is like telling them to 'be taller'.
phrase_2: Your thought is important, AND my ears are listening to (Grandma) right now. I need you to do *one* job: put your hand on my arm. That's the 'I'm next' signal.
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the thought. State the boundary. Give them *one* physical 'job' to do *while waiting*.
avoid_step2: Don't expect them to just 'stand there' and wait. Their brain *can't* do that.
phrase_3: You're in charge of the 'signal'. [When they put hand on you, pat it]. I feel you. I see you. I'll be with you in *one* minute. [Finish your sentence]. Okay, I'm all yours.
say_it_like_this_step3: Empower them with a *tool* for waiting. The physical connection (hand on arm) 'anchors' their brain and provides the external support to *not* interrupt.
avoid_step3: You *must* acknowledge the signal and then turn to them quickly.
neurological_tip: This is an 'inhibitory control' challenge. They aren't rude; they are impulsive. The 'hand on arm' signal is a concrete *action* they can do *instead* of interrupting.
what_to_expect_1: It works because it gives their impulse a *job*.
what_to_expect_2: This teaches a vital social skill in a brain-friendly way.

title: Dawdling (Lost in Thought)
wrong_way: What are you doing? We're late! You're just staring at the wall! Shoes! NOW!
phrase_1: [Walk over. Wave hand gently in front of eyes]. Hey. Earth to [Name]. [Smile]. You're 'zoning'. You're lost in a thought.
say_it_like_this_step1: Be gentle and playful. This is 'internal distraction'. Don't startle them.
avoid_step1: Don't be angry. Don't yell. Don't assume they are 'ignoring' you. They are 'gone'.
phrase_2: It's fun to think, AND it's time for 'Step 2' (shoes). Let's get your brain back. What's the *one* thing you're supposed to be doing?
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the 'zoning'. State the boundary. Ask a question to *pull* their executive function back online.
avoid_step2: Don't list all the things. Just 'one' thing.
phrase_3: Right, 'shoes'. You're in charge of shoes. Let's make it a game. Can you get them on before I count to 20? I'll count slowly.
say_it_like_this_step3: Empower them by 'gamifying' the task. This gives their brain a *focus point* (the counting) and a *deadline* (20).
avoid_step3: Don't rush them. The 'game' is the scaffold.
neurological_tip: This is the *internal* distraction (80% of ADHD). Their brain just 'wandered off'. You are their 'anchor' to pull it back, gently.
what_to_expect_1: Be prepared to 'pull them back' 3-4 times every morning.
what_to_expect_2: This is a core feature of their brain, not a 'bad habit'.

title: Forgetting Items (Backpack, Lunch)
wrong_way: This is the THIRD time you forgot your lunch! Why can't you remember?
phrase_1: [At the door]. Okay, time for the 'Launch Pad Check'. [Point to a visual checklist by the door]. Let's check the list.
say_it_like_this_step1: Be a 'co-pilot', not a 'critic'. This is a 'system' check, not a 'you' check.
avoid_step1: Don't rely on their memory. Ever. Don't get angry at the 'forgetting'. It's inevitable.
phrase_2: It's hard to hold all the 'things' in your head, AND this list is our 'external brain'. What's 'Step 1' on the list?
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the *working memory* challenge. Introduce the *tool* (the list). Ask them to do *one* step.
avoid_step2: Don't just hand them the forgotten item. This teaches them nothing.
phrase_3: 'Backpack'. You're in charge. Do you have it? [Wait for 'yes']. 'Lunch'. Do you have it? [Wait]. 'Water'. Do you have it? You're the 'Checklist Boss'.
say_it_like_this_step3: Empower them by making them the 'boss' of the *list*. You are teaching them to use a *system* to support their working memory.
avoid_step3: Don't do the list *for* them. They must do the checking.
neurological_tip: Working memory failure is the #1 symptom. Do not *ever* rely on a distracted child's memory for 'exit' tasks. A visual checklist (with pictures) *is* the solution.
what_to_expect_1: The goal is not to have them 'remember'. The goal is to teach them to use the 'system'.
what_to_expect_2: This is a 100% solvable problem *if* you use a visual system.

title: Too Tired to Function
wrong_way: Stop being lazy. Get up! You're fine. You slept enough.
phrase_1: Your 'engine' is cold. It's really hard to 'start' your body in the morning. You're still in 'sleep mode'.
say_it_like_this_step1: Be very gentle. Keep lights low. Sit on bed. Speak slowly.
avoid_step1: Don't be a 'drill sergeant'. Don't be overly cheerful. Don't rush them.
phrase_2: It's hard to 'turn on' your brain, AND the day has to start. Let's start with *one* small thing. Your job: sit up. [Wait]. Great. Now, 'feet on floor'.
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the 'fog'. State the boundary. Give *micro-steps*. 'Get dressed' is 10 steps. 'Sit up' is one.
avoid_step2: Don't give any other commands.
phrase_3: You did it. You're sitting. Awesome. You're in charge of the next step. I'm going to put your 'on-ramp' music on. [Put on one specific 'wake up' song].
say_it_like_this_step3: Empower them by narrating their success. Use an *auditory cue* (music) as a transition 'on-ramp'. This 'song' can become a 'timer'.
avoid_step3: Don't expect them to 'snap out of it'. This 'brain fog' is real.
neurological_tip: This isn't 'laziness'. This is a massive 'task-initiation' failure. Their 'engine' is flooded. You have to 'scaffold' them, step-by-step, into a 'running' state.
what_to_expect_1: The single-song 'timer' is very effective. 'You have to have shoes on by the end of this song.'
what_to_expect_2: This requires patience, but it avoids the 'morning war'.

title: Forgets to Eat (Lost in Thought)
wrong_way: Eat your breakfast! We're leaving in 5 minutes! Stop staring into space!
phrase_1: [Gently tap spoon on bowl]. Hey. You're 'zoning' again. You forgot you were eating.
say_it_like_this_step1: Gently, kindly, bring them back. A physical cue (tap) is good.
avoid_step1: Don't get mad. Don't take it personally.
phrase_2: It's easy to get 'lost', AND we have 5 minutes left to eat. (Point to visual timer). Let's 'race the timer'. Your job: take *three* 'timer-racing' bites. Show me.
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate. State the *visual* boundary (timer). 'Gamify' the task.
avoid_step2: Don't just say 'Hurry up!'. That's not an instruction, it's a 'stress-state'.
phrase_3: You're in charge of the 'race'. Let's see if you can 'win' (i.e., finish). Three more bites! Go!
say_it_like_this_step3: Empower them by making them the 'racer'. This gives their brain a *focus point* (the timer) and a *goal* (beat it).
avoid_step3: Don't let them 'lose' and be 'punished'. Just use it to keep them 'on task'.
neurological_tip: Their brain 'wandered off' mid-meal. It's not defiance. A visual timer (like a TimeTimer or sand timer) provides the external, concrete 'boundary' for time that they lack internally.
what_to_expect_1: This is a 'task-monitoring' failure. The timer is the external 'monitor'.
what_to_expect_2: This works. It keeps the morning moving and (mostly) calm.
what_to_expect_3: Mealtime-Too Distracted to Eat|Morning_Routines-Dawdling (Lost in Thought)

title: Hyperactive/Restless (Can't Sit Still)
wrong_way: Sit STILL! You are driving me crazy. If you don't calm down, we're leaving!
phrase_1: Your body is a 'race car' right now! It has SO much energy, it can't be still! Vroom!
say_it_like_this_step1: Use a playful, energetic tone, but with a *goal*. 'Match' their energy, then *redirect* it.
avoid_step1: Don't get angry. Don't try to 'squash' the energy. This will lead to an explosion.
phrase_2: That's a lot of 'vroom'! AND this is not a 'vroom' place (e.g., store). We need to give that 'vroom' a *job*. Your job: 'Heavy Work'. Can you *push* this heavy cart?
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the *energy*. State the *boundary*. Offer a *physical, productive job*.
avoid_step2: Don't say 'Stop it' or 'Calm down'. Their body *can't*.
phrase_3: You're in charge of the 'engine'. Let's see you use your 'strong-pushing' muscles. Push the cart. You're doing 'heavy work' to help your engine 'idle'.
say_it_like_this_step3: Empower them with a *tool*. Proprioceptive input ('heavy work' like pushing, pulling, carrying) is *neurologically calming* to a hyperactive brain.
avoid_step3: Don't give them a 'running' job. Give them a 'pushing/pulling' job.
neurological_tip: This isn't a tantrum, it's a 'boiling over' of sensory/motor needs. You're not punishing, you're *redirecting* the energy into a safe, productive, and neurologically-organizing task.
what_to_expect_1: This is a 'meltdown-prevention' script.
what_to_expect_2: This is the #1 tool for 'hyperactive' kids. Give them heavy work.

title: Frustration Meltdown (Can't Do It)
wrong_way: Stop crying! It's just a block/zipper! It's not hard! Let me do it.
phrase_1: You are SO frustrated! That (zipper) won't work and you're 'stuck'. That's a 'rage' feeling.
say_it_like_this_step1: Get to their level. Use an empathetic tone. Name the feeling ('frustrated', 'stuck', 'rage').
avoid_step1: Don't 'take over' and do it for them. Don't minimize the problem ('it's easy').
phrase_2: It's hard, AND you're 'stuck'. Let's do a 'Brain Reset'. Your job: stand up, shake your hands *fast* (10 seconds). [Do it with them]. Okay. Try again.
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate. State the problem. Offer a *physical 'reset'*. This is a 'pattern interrupt'.
avoid_step2: Don't offer to 'help' first. Offer a 'reset' first.
phrase_3: You're in charge of the 'reset'. Let's get that 'stuck' feeling out. [Shake]. Good. Now, let's look at the zipper *together*. What's the *first* step?
say_it_like_this_step3: Empower them by giving them a *tool* for frustration. The physical 'shake' discharges the 'stuck' energy. Then, *break down* the problem ('What's the *first* step?').
avoid_step3: Don't try to solve the *whole* zipper. Just 'Step 1' (e.g., 'get the bottom part together').
neurological_tip: This is an 'executive function' failure. The frustration 'hijacks' the problem-solving part of the brain. The 'reset' gets the amygdala offline, and the 'Step 1' question engages the (now calm) prefrontal cortex.
what_to_expect_1: They are learning *how* to handle frustration, not just 'get the zipper done'.
what_to_expect_2: This is a critical life skill.

title: Fatigue-Induced Meltdown
wrong_way: Stop it! You're just tired! Go to sleep! Why are you crying?
phrase_1: Your 'battery' is at 0%. You are *done*. Your whole body is out of 'power' and 'control'.
say_it_like_this_step1: Stop everything. The 'agenda' (dinner, bath) is over. Pick them up. Move to a dark, quiet room.
avoid_step1: Don't try to 'reason' or 'finish the routine'. Don't get mad.
phrase_2: You're 'done', AND I've got you. You are safe. Your *only* job is to 'be'. I'll do the rest. [Hold them, rock slowly].
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the 'done' feeling. State the *safety*. Give them *one* job: 'be'.
avoid_step2: Don't ask questions. Don't require anything.
phrase_3: You're in charge of 'resting'. I'm in charge of 'holding'. We're a good team. Shhh.
say_it_like_this_step3: Empower them by giving them *permission* to shut down. You are their 'external battery' and 'external brain'.
avoid_step3: Don't talk. Just 'be' with them.
neurological_tip: This is a total 'system crash'. Their executive functions are *gone*. They can't walk, talk, or think. They are 100% 'downstairs brain' (brainstem). Your job is to co-regulate them back to safety.
what_to_expect_1: This is not a 'tantrum'. This is a 'crash'.
what_to_expect_2: Don't worry about PJs or brushing teeth. Sleep is the only goal.

title: Sensory Meltdown (DISTRACTED)
wrong_way: Stop screaming! What is wrong with you? Calm down!
phrase_1: [Quiet, firm voice]. It's too much. Too loud. Too bright. Your brain is 'full'.
say_it_like_this_step1: Reduce sensory input *immediately*. Dim lights. Turn off TV. Move to a quiet space.
avoid_step1: Don't add *more* sensory input (yelling, touching, asking questions).
phrase_2: It's 'too much', AND you are safe. Your *one* job: sit here. [Hand them a 'heavy' (weighted) item]. Hold this.
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the *overwhelm*. State the *safety*. Give *one* concrete, physical 'anchor' job.
avoid_step2: Don't try to 'talk it out'. The brain is not processing language.
phrase_3: You're in charge of 'holding this'. That's your *only* job. I'm right here.
say_it_like_this_step3: Empower them by giving their 'body' a job, which frees their 'brain' to reset. The deep pressure (proprioception) from the heavy item is neurologically *calming* and *organizing*.
avoid_step3: Don't try to 'fix' the trigger. Just 'ride out' the storm.
neurological_tip: A distracted/ADHD brain is *more* susceptible to sensory overload because the 'filter' (executive function) is weaker. The 'meltdown' is the 'filter' breaking. The 'heavy' item helps 'reboot' the filter.
what_to_expect_1: This will pass in 5-10 minutes if you *reduce* stimuli.
what_to_expect_2: This is a neurological event, not a behavior.

title: Impulsive Grabbing (Toys)
wrong_way: No! We don't grab! Say sorry! That was so rude.
phrase_1: [Gently take hand. Get to eye level]. Whoa! You saw that truck and your hand grabbed it *fast*! Your 'hand-brain' was faster than your 'thinking-brain'.
say_it_like_this_step1: Be gentle, but firm. Get on their level. Narrate the *impulse* as a 'fast hand'.
avoid_step1: Don't shame ('rude'). Don't just force the 'sorry'.
phrase_2: Your 'hand' forgot the rule, AND the rule is 'we ask first'. Let's do a 'Re-Do'. Give the truck back [help them], and you can be in charge of *asking*.
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the *impulse*. State the *rule*. Offer an *immediate 'Re-Do'*. This is the key.
avoid_step2: Don't just punish. *Teach* the replacement behavior.
phrase_3: You're in charge of your 'asking' voice. Let's try. 'Can I have that?' You did it! Now, let's see what [friend] says.
say_it_like_this_step3: Empower them to 'do it right'. The 'Re-Do' is their chance to 'win'. This rewires the brain.
avoid_step3: Don't get mad if the other kid says 'no'. That's the next lesson. 'He said no. You can find another toy. You did a great job asking.'
neurological_tip: This is a 100% 'inhibitory control' failure. Their brain *saw* and *did*. The 'Re-Do' is a *physical* practice of 'inhibitory control' (giving back) and 'task initiation' (asking).
what_to_expect_1: This is *not* 'badness'. It's 'fastness'.
what_to_expect_2: Praise the 'asking', regardless of the outcome.

title: Impulsive Pushing/Hitting
wrong_way: We DON'T HIT! Go to time-out! NOW!
phrase_1: [Remove them immediately, firmly but not angrily]. Whoa. Your body moved 'too fast' and 'too hard' and it hit [friend].
say_it_like_this_step1: Your first job is safety. Move them away. Get on their level. Be *calM* and *firm*.
avoid_step1: Don't scream. Don't shame ('You're a bad boy'). Don't just banish them to time-out (they won't connect the action to the punishment).
phrase_2: Your body was 'too fast', AND the rule is 'safe hands'. Your friend is hurt. Your *one* job right now: sit here with me and 'calm your engine'.
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the *impulse* ('too fast'). State the *rule* and the *impact* ('friend is hurt'). Give *one* 'reg-down' job.
avoid_step2: Don't force the 'sorry' yet. Their brain is still 'hot'.
phrase_3: You're in charge of 'calming your engine'. When your engine is 'idle', we will go get 'ice' for [friend]. That's the 'helper' job.
say_it_like_this_step3: Empower them with a *two-step plan*. 1. Regulate. 2. *Repair*. The 'repair' (getting ice) is the *consequence* and the *lesson*.
avoid_step3: Don't just punish. *Repair*.
neurological_tip: This is an 'inhibitory control' failure. They *can't* 'calm down' on command. They need a *process*. 'Sit' (calm), then 'Repair' (helper job) *teaches* the 'full-stop' and 'repair' sequence.
what_to_expect_1: The 'repair' step (getting ice, a wet paper towel) is the most important part. It teaches empathy and responsibility.
what_to_expect_2: They learn 'My fast body made a mistake. My 'helper' body can fix it.'

title: Interrupting (Impulsive)
wrong_way: Stop! I'm talking! It's rude to interrupt! Wait your turn!
phrase_1: [Gently put your hand up in a 'stop' signal]. I see you have a 'bubble' of a thought! It wants to pop out!
say_it_like_this_step1: Use a *physical signal* (the hand) and a *playful metaphor* ('thought bubble').
avoid_step1: Don't get angry. Don't shame ('rude').
phrase_2: It's hard to hold that 'bubble'! AND my ears are busy. Your job: put your hand on my arm. That's the 'I'm next' signal.
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the *difficulty* of waiting. State the boundary. Give them a *physical 'waiting' job* (hand on arm).
avoid_step2: Don't expect them to just 'wait'. Their brain *can't* do that.
phrase_3: [When they put hand on you, pat it]. I feel you. I see you. I'll be with you in *one* minute. [Finish your sentence]. Okay, my ears are yours. Pop the bubble!
say_it_like_this_step3: Empower them with a *tool* that works. The physical 'hand on arm' *anchors* their thought, so their brain doesn't 'lose it' (which is *why* they interrupt).
avoid_step3: You *must* acknowledge the signal and get to them quickly.
neurological_tip: This is an 'inhibitory control' and 'working memory' failure. They interrupt because they are afraid they will *forget* their thought. The 'hand on arm' gives them a physical anchor for the thought.
what_to_expect_1: This. Works. It's respectful and brain-based.
what_to_expect_2: Praise them: 'You used the signal! That was awesome.'

title: Distracted During Group Time
wrong_way: Sit down! Pay attention! Everyone else is listening!
phrase_1: [Teacher/Parent moves close. Gentle touch on shoulder]. Hey. I need your eyes. You 'drifted' away. Come on back.
say_it_like_this_step1: Use physical proximity and a gentle touch to 'reel them back in'.
avoid_step1: Don't call them out publicly. Don't compare them.
phrase_2: It's hard to focus, AND it's story time. Let's 'anchor' your body. Your job: can you be the 'ground-keeper' and make sure your 'bottom' is 'stuck to the floor'?
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the *drift*. State the boundary. Give them *one* physical 'anchor' job.
avoid_step2: Don't just say 'Pay attention'. That's not a real instruction.
phrase_3: You're in charge of 'sticking' to the floor. Show me. Great. Now, let's get your ears 'stuck' on the story.
say_it_like_this_step3: Empower them by giving them a *physical* 'anchor' task. This gives their brain a 'grounding' point so the 'mind' can focus.
avoid_step3: Don't expect it to last. You may have to 'reel them in' 2-3 times.
neurological_tip: Their brain is 'wandering'. It's not 'badness'. A physical 'anchor' (bottom on floor, hands in lap) gives their 'wiggles' a job, which frees up the brain to listen.
what_to_expect_1: Proximity is your best tool. The closer you are, the more 'anchored' they are.
what_to_expect_2: This is about 'support', not 'discipline'.
what_to_expect_3: Mealtime-Gets Up from Table|Bedtime-Distracted During Story

title: Distracted in Bath (Playing)
wrong_way: Stop playing! We have to wash! You're getting water everywhere!
phrase_1: You are having a *great* time with those cups! You're a 'water scientist'.
say_it_like_this_step1: Use a playful tone. Enter *their* world first.
avoid_step1: Don't just yell 'Stop!'. Don't get mad about the 'mess' (it's a bath).
phrase_2: You love those cups, AND we have a 'mission'. We have to find the 'soap' and get the 'dirt'. Your *first* job: find the washcloth. Where is it?
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the play. State the *mission* (gamify). Give *one* single 'Step 1' command.
avoid_step2: Don't say 'It's time to wash'. That's abstract.
phrase_3: You found it! Great. You're in charge of 'Step 2': put soap on it. [Wait]. Good! 'Step 3': wash your 'tummy'. [Narrate each step].
say_it_like_this_step3: Empower them by making *them* the 'doer' of each *one* micro-step. You are their 'mission control', narrating the sequence.
avoid_step3: Don't give the sequence 'Wash your tummy, arms, and legs'. Just *one* at a time.
neurological_tip: The 'play' *is* the distraction. You have to 'break in' gently, and then 'scaffold' the *real* task (washing) by breaking it into 5-6 micro-steps.
what_to_expect_1: They *will* get distracted again mid-way. Just gently 'reel them back in'. 'Okay, 'tummy' is done. Next mission: 'arms'!'
what_to_expect_2: This makes bath time a *game*, not a *fight*.
what_to_expect_3: Hygiene-Forgot to Wash Hands|Mealtime-Forgets to Eat

title: Forgot to Wash Hands (Ran Past Sink)
wrong_way: Get back here! You forgot to wash your hands! That's gross!
phrase_1: [Stand by sink. Block the path. Be playful]. Whoa, fast feet! You 'flew' right past the sink! Your 'feet-brain' was faster than your 'hand-brain'.
say_it_like_this_step1: Be a 'playful barrier'. You're not mad, you're a 'gate'.
avoid_step1: Don't shame ('gross'). Don't get angry.
phrase_2: You're in a hurry to (eat/play), AND we have 'Step 1' first. The 'soap' step. Your job: 'Germs'. You're in charge of 'getting the germs'. [Put soap on their hands].
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the *impulse* (hurry). State the *boundary* (Step 1). Give *one* 'gamified' job.
avoid_step2: Don't just say 'Wash your hands'.
phrase_3: You're the 'Germ Boss'. You have to 'fight' them with bubbles. Let's see you 'fight' them for 20 seconds. [Sing a song]. You did it!
say_it_like_this_step3: Empower them by making them the 'Boss' of the task. The song provides an *external, auditory timer* for how long to wash.
avoid_step3: Don't just let them 'rinse and run'. The 'timer song' is the key.
neurological_tip: They 100% *forgot*. They did not 'defy' the sink. Their brain was on the *next* thing (food) and skipped the 'middle' step. You are the 'external brain' that *reminds* them.
what_to_expect_1: A visual 'STOP' sign on the sink, or a chart, is also very effective.
what_to_expect_2: This is a working memory/sequencing failure.
what_to_expect_3: Transitions-Forgets Instructions|Mealtime-Forgets to Come to Table

title: Rushing Through Brushing Teeth
wrong_way: That was 10 seconds! That's not brushing! Get back in here and do it right!
phrase_1: Whoa, that was 'fast-forward' brushing! You got the 'big' parts, but we need to get the 'sneaky' parts.
say_it_like_this_step1: Be playful. Acknowledge the 'speed'.
avoid_step1: Don't shame. Don't get angry.
phrase_2: You want to be 'done', AND the 'sugar bugs' are still hiding. We need a 'timer'. Your job: you can be in charge of 'pushing the button' on the 2-minute timer (song/electric brush).
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the desire ('done'). State the boundary ('sugar bugs'). Offer a *tool* (timer) as the 'boss'.
avoid_step2: Don't just say 'Brush more'. That's not a real instruction.
phrase_3: You're the 'Button Boss'. [Start timer]. You have to keep brushing until the 'Boss' (the timer) says 'stop'. Let's hunt for those bugs! [Narrate]. 'Get the top ones! Get the back ones!'
say_it_like_this_step3: Empower them by making *them* charge of the *tool*. The *timer* is the 'boss', not you. Narrating ('get the tops') helps their brain 'focus' on the micro-task.
avoid_step3: Don't walk away. They will 'zone out'. Stay and 'narrate' the 2 minutes.
neurological_tip: Their internal 'clock' is non-existent. They have no idea what 2 minutes feels like. A visual or auditory timer (like a 2-min song) is the *only* way to provide the external structure they need.
what_to_expect_1: This makes you a 'helper', not a 'nag'.
what_to_expect_2: This works every time.

title: Forgot to Flush / Wash (Distracted)
wrong_way: Ugh, you forgot to flush! Again! Go back and do it! And did you wash?
phrase_1: [Stand at bathroom door]. Hey, you finished 'Step 1' (pee/poop). Your *one* next job is 'flush'. Go do it and come show me.
say_it_like_this_step1: Be a 'coach'. Be neutral. This is a sequencing-and-memory problem.
avoid_step1: Don't shame. Don't show disgust. Don't yell from the other room.
phrase_2: You're in a hurry, AND we have the '3 Steps'. Let's see the chart. 1. Potty. 2. Flush. 3. Wash. You did 1. What's 2?
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the 'hurry'. Point to a *visual chart* (pictures of the 3 steps).
avoid_step2: Don't assume they 'know' this. They 'know' it, but they *forget* it.
phrase_3: 'Flush'! You got it. You're the 'Flush Boss'. [Wait]. Great! What's Step 3? 'Wash'! You're the 'Wash Boss'. [Go with them].
say_it_like_this_step3: Empower them by making them the 'Boss' of each *single step*. You *must* break this down. A visual chart on the wall is 100% necessary.
avoid_step3: Don't just tell them to 'go back and wash'. They will forget to flush. Walk them back and 'scaffold' the *entire* sequence.
neurological_tip: This is a classic 'working memory' failure. Their brain is 'Done!' after the 'potty' step and 'drops' the rest of the sequence. The visual chart is their 'external brain'.
what_to_expect_1: Praise the *sequence*. 'You did all 3 steps! High five!'
what_to_expect_2: This is 100% solvable with a visual chart and 'one-step-at-a-time' coaching.
